std = @import(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"std\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\");\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n// Although this function looks imperative, it does not perform the build\\\\\\\\n// directly and instead it mutates the build graph (&#96;b&#96;) that will be then\\\\\\\\n// executed by an external runner. The functions in &#96;std.Build&#96; implement a DSL\\\\\\\\n// for defining build steps and express dependencies between them, allowing the\\\\\\\\n// build runner to parallelize the build automatically (and the cache system to\\\\\\\\n// know when a step doesn't need to be re-run).\\\\\\\\npub fn build(b: *std.Build) void {\\\\\\\\n    // Standard target options allow the person running &#96;zig build&#96; to choose\\\\\\\\n    // what target to build for. Here we do not override the defaults, which\\\\\\\\n    // means any target is allowed, and the default is native. Other options\\\\\\\\n    // for restricting supported target set are available.\\\\\\\\n    const target = b.standardTargetOptions(.{});\\\\\\\\n    // Standard optimization options allow the person running &#96;zig build&#96; to select\\\\\\\\n    // between Debug, ReleaseSafe, ReleaseFast, and ReleaseSmall. Here we do not\\\\\\\\n    // set a preferred release mode, allowing the user to decide how to optimize.\\\\\\\\n    const optimize = b.standardOptimizeOption(.{});\\\\\\\\n    // It's also possible to define more custom flags to toggle optional features\\\\\\\\n    // of this build script using &#96;b.option()&#96;. All defined flags (including\\\\\\\\n    // target and optimize options) will be listed when running &#96;zig build --help&#96;\\\\\\\\n    // in this directory.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    // Low-level bindings modules for CLAP and VST3\\\\\\\\n    const clap_bindings = b.addModule(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"clap-bindings\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", .{\\\\\\\\n        .root_source_file = b.path(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"src/bindings/clap/main.zig\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"),\\\\\\\\n        .target = target,\\\\\\\\n    });\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    const vst3_bindings = b.addModule(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"vst3-bindings\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", .{\\\\\\\\n        .root_source_file = b.path(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"src/bindings/vst3/root.zig\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"),\\\\\\\\n        .target = target,\\\\\\\\n    });\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    // Main framework module\\\\\\\\n    const mod = b.addModule(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"z_plug\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", .{\\\\\\\\n        .root_source_file = b.path(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"src/root.zig\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"),\\\\\\\\n        .target = target,\\\\\\\\n        .imports = &amp;.{\\\\\\\\n            .{ .name = \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"clap-bindings\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", .module = clap_bindings },\\\\\\\\n            .{ .name = \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"vst3-bindings\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", .module = vst3_bindings },\\\\\\\\n        },\\\\\\\\n    });\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    // Here we define an executable. An executable needs to have a root module\\\\\\\\n    // which needs to expose a &#96;main&#96; function. While we could add a main function\\\\\\\\n    // to the module defined above, it's sometimes preferable to split business\\\\\\\\n    // logic and the CLI into two separate modules.\\\\\\\\n    //\\\\\\\\n    // If your goal is to create a Zig library for others to use, consider if\\\\\\\\n    // it might benefit from also exposing a CLI tool. A parser library for a\\\\\\\\n    // data serialization format could also bundle a CLI syntax checker, for example.\\\\\\\\n    //\\\\\\\\n    // If instead your goal is to create an executable, consider if users might\\\\\\\\n    // be interested in also being able to embed the core functionality of your\\\\\\\\n    // program in their own executable in order to avoid the overhead involved in\\\\\\\\n    // subprocessing your CLI tool.\\\\\\\\n    //\\\\\\\\n    // If neither case applies to you, feel free to delete the declaration you\\\\\\\\n    // don't need and to put everything under a single module.\\\\\\\\n    const exe = b.addExecutable(.{\\\\\\\\n        .name = \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"z_plug\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\\n        .root_module = b.createModule(.{\\\\\\\\n            // b.createModule defines a new module just like b.addModule but,\\\\\\\\n            // unlike b.addModule, it does not expose the module to consumers of\\\\\\\\n            // this package, which is why in this case we don't have to give it a name.\\\\\\\\n            .root_source_file = b.path(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"src/main.zig\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"),\\\\\\\\n            // Target and optimization levels must be explicitly wired in when\\\\\\\\n            // defining an executable or library (in the root module), and you\\\\\\\\n            // can also hardcode a specific target for an executable or library\\\\\\\\n            // definition if desireable (e.g. firmware for embedded devices).\\\\\\\\n            .target = target,\\\\\\\\n            .optimize = optimize,\\\\\\\\n            // List of modules available for import in source files part of the\\\\\\\\n            // root module.\\\\\\\\n            .imports = &amp;.{\\\\\\\\n                // Here \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"z_plug\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\" is the name you will use in your source code to\\\\\\\\n                // import this module (e.g. &#96;@import(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"z_plug\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\")&#96;). The name is\\\\\\\\n                // repeated because you are allowed to rename your imports, which\\\\\\\\n                // can be extremely useful in case of collisions (which can happen\\\\\\\\n                // importing modules from different packages).\\\\\\\\n                .{ .name = \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"z_plug\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", .module = mod },\\\\\\\\n            },\\\\\\\\n        }),\\\\\\\\n    });\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    // This declares intent for the executable to be installed into the\\\\\\\\n    // install prefix when running &#96;zig build&#96; (i.e. when executing the default\\\\\\\\n    // step). By default the install prefix is &#96;zig-out/&#96; but can be overridden\\\\\\\\n    // by passing &#96;--prefix&#96; or &#96;-p&#96;.\\\\\\\\n    b.installArtifact(exe);\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    // This creates a top level step. Top level steps have a name and can be\\\\\\\\n    // invoked by name when running &#96;zig build&#96; (e.g. &#96;zig build run&#96;).\\\\\\\\n    // This will evaluate the &#96;run&#96; step rather than the default step.\\\\\\\\n    // For a top level step to actually do something, it must depend on other\\\\\\\\n    // steps (e.g. a Run step, as we will see in a moment).\\\\\\\\n    const run_step = b.step(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"run\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"Run the app\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\");\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    // This creates a RunArtifact step in the build graph. A RunArtifact step\\\\\\\\n    // invokes an executable compiled by Zig. Steps will only be executed by the\\\\\\\\n    // runner if invoked directly by the user (in the case of top level steps)\\\\\\\\n    // or if another step depends on it, so it's up to you to define when and\\\\\\\\n    // how this Run step will be executed. In our case we want to run it when\\\\\\\\n    // the user runs &#96;zig build run&#96;, so we create a dependency link.\\\\\\\\n    const run_cmd = b.addRunArtifact(exe);\\\\\\\\n    run_step.dependOn(&amp;run_cmd.step);\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    // By making the run step depend on the default step, it will be run from the\\\\\\\\n    // installation directory rather than directly from within the cache directory.\\\\\\\\n    run_cmd.step.dependOn(b.getInstallStep());\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    // This allows the user to pass arguments to the application in the build\\\\\\\\n    // command itself, like this: &#96;zig build run -- arg1 arg2 etc&#96;\\\\\\\\n    if (b.args) |args| {\\\\\\\\n        run_cmd.addArgs(args);\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    // Creates an executable that will run &#96;test&#96; blocks from the provided module.\\\\\\\\n    // Here &#96;mod&#96; needs to define a target, which is why earlier we made sure to\\\\\\\\n    // set the releative field.\\\\\\\\n    const mod_tests = b.addTest(.{\\\\\\\\n        .root_module = mod,\\\\\\\\n    });\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    // Test the CLAP bindings\\\\\\\\n    const clap_tests = b.addTest(.{\\\\\\\\n        .root_module = clap_bindings,\\\\\\\\n    });\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    // Test the VST3 bindings\\\\\\\\n    const vst3_tests = b.addTest(.{\\\\\\\\n        .root_module = vst3_bindings,\\\\\\\\n    });\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    // A run step that will run the test executable.\\\\\\\\n    const run_mod_tests = b.addRunArtifact(mod_tests);\\\\\\\\n    const run_clap_tests = b.addRunArtifact(clap_tests);\\\\\\\\n    const run_vst3_tests = b.addRunArtifact(vst3_tests);\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    // Creates an executable that will run &#96;test&#96; blocks from the executable's\\\\\\\\n    // root module. Note that test executables only test one module at a time,\\\\\\\\n    // hence why we have to create two separate ones.\\\\\\\\n    const exe_tests = b.addTest(.{\\\\\\\\n        .root_module = exe.root_module,\\\\\\\\n    });\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    // A run step that will run the second test executable.\\\\\\\\n    const run_exe_tests = b.addRunArtifact(exe_tests);\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    // A top level step for running all tests. dependOn can be called multiple\\\\\\\\n    // times and since the two run steps do not depend on one another, this will\\\\\\\\n    // make the two of them run in parallel.\\\\\\\\n    const test_step = b.step(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"test\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"Run tests\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\");\\\\\\\\n    test_step.dependOn(&amp;run_mod_tests.step);\\\\\\\\n    test_step.dependOn(&amp;run_clap_tests.step);\\\\\\\\n    test_step.dependOn(&amp;run_vst3_tests.step);\\\\\\\\n    test_step.dependOn(&amp;run_exe_tests.step);\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    // Just like flags, top level steps are also listed in the &#96;--help&#96; menu.\\\\\\\\n    //\\\\\\\\n    // The Zig build system is entirely implemented in userland, which means\\\\\\\\n    // that it cannot hook into private compiler APIs. All compilation work\\\\\\\\n    // orchestrated by the build system will result in other Zig compiler\\\\\\\\n    // subcommands being invoked with the right flags defined. You can observe\\\\\\\\n    // these invocations when one fails (or you pass a flag to increase\\\\\\\\n    // verbosity) to validate assumptions and diagnose problems.\\\\\\\\n    //\\\\\\\\n    // Lastly, the Zig build system is relatively simple and self-contained,\\\\\\\\n    // and reading its source code will allow you to master it.\\\\\\\\n}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"totalLinesInFile\\\\\\\":172}\\\"},\\\"capabilityType\\\":15}\",\"aaf489c8-4f4b-4104-a488-3ad4d00165d8\":\"{\\\"_v\\\":3,\\\"type\\\":2,\\\"approximateLintErrors\\\":[],\\\"lints\\\":[],\\\"codebaseContextChunks\\\":[],\\\"commits\\\":[],\\\"pullRequests\\\":[],\\\"attachedCodeChunks\\\":[],\\\"assistantSuggestedDiffs\\\":[],\\\"gitDiffs\\\":[],\\\"interpreterResults\\\":[],\\\"images\\\":[],\\\"attachedFolders\\\":[],\\\"attachedFoldersNew\\\":[],\\\"bubbleId\\\":\\\"2affe9f4-83b7-4cde-b07c-6e589c0f59b3\\\",\\\"userResponsesToSuggestedCodeBlocks\\\":[],\\\"suggestedCodeBlocks\\\":[],\\\"diffsForCompressingFiles\\\":[],\\\"relevantFiles\\\":[],\\\"toolResults\\\":[],\\\"notepads\\\":[],\\\"capabilities\\\":[],\\\"multiFileLinterErrors\\\":[],\\\"diffHistories\\\":[],\\\"recentLocationsHistory\\\":[],\\\"recentlyViewedFiles\\\":[],\\\"isAgentic\\\":false,\\\"fileDiffTrajectories\\\":[],\\\"existedSubsequentTerminalCommand\\\":false,\\\"existedPreviousTerminalCommand\\\":false,\\\"docsReferences\\\":[],\\\"webReferences\\\":[],\\\"aiWebSearchResults\\\":[],\\\"requestId\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"attachedFoldersListDirResults\\\":[],\\\"humanChanges\\\":[],\\\"attachedHumanChanges\\\":false,\\\"summarizedComposers\\\":[],\\\"cursorRules\\\":[],\\\"contextPieces\\\":[],\\\"editTrailContexts\\\":[],\\\"allThinkingBlocks\\\":[],\\\"diffsSinceLastApply\\\":[],\\\"deletedFiles\\\":[],\\\"supportedTools\\\":[],\\\"tokenCount\\\":{\\\"inputTokens\\\":0,\\\"outputTokens\\\":0},\\\"attachedFileCodeChunksMetadataOnly\\\":[],\\\"consoleLogs\\\":[],\\\"uiElementPicked\\\":[],\\\"isRefunded\\\":false,\\\"knowledgeItems\\\":[],\\\"documentationSelections\\\":[],\\\"externalLinks\\\":[],\\\"projectLayouts\\\":[],\\\"unifiedMode\\\":2,\\\"capabilityContexts\\\":[],\\\"todos\\\":[],\\\"createdAt\\\":\\\"2026-02-16T20:45:57.850Z\\\",\\\"mcpDescriptors\\\":[],\\\"workspaceUris\\\":[],\\\"conversationState\\\":{\\\"rootPromptMessagesJson\\\":[],\\\"turnsOld\\ object by caching its pointer.\\\\\\\\n    /// important:\\\\\\\\n    ///  - the cookie is invalidated by a full parameter rescan or when the\\\\\\\\n    ///    plugin is destroyed.\\\\\\\\n    ///  - the host will either provide the cookie as issued or null in events\\\\\\\\n    ///    addressing parameters.\\\\\\\\n    ///  - the plugin must gracefully handle the case of a cookie which is null\\\\\\\\n    ///  - many plugins will process the parameter events more quickly if the\\\\\\\\n    ///    host can provide the cookie in a faster time than a hashmap lookup\\\\\\\\n    ///    per param per event.\\\\\\\\n    cookie: ?*anyopaque,\\\\\\\\n    /// the display name. eg: \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"Volume\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\". this does not need to be unique. do not\\\\\\\\n    /// include the Adapters and utilities for working with audio buffers.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nuse std::marker::PhantomData;\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nmod blocks;\\\\\\\\nmod samples;\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\npub use blocks::{Block, BlockChannelsIter, BlocksIter};\\\\\\\\npub use samples::{ChannelSamples, ChannelSamplesIter, SamplesIter};\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n/// The audio buffers used during processing. This contains the output audio output buffers with the\\\\\\\\n/// inputs already copied to the outputs. You can either use the iterator adapters to conveniently\\\\\\\\n/// and efficiently iterate over the samples, or you can do your own thing using the raw audio\\\\\\\\n/// buffers.\\\\\\\\n///\\\\\\\\n/// TODO: This lifetime makes zero sense because you're going to need unsafe lifetime casts to use\\\\\\\\n///       this either way. Maybe just get rid of it in favor for raw pointers.\\\\\\\\n#[derive(Default)]\\\\\\\\npub struct Buffer&lt;'a&gt; {\\\\\\\\n    /// The number of samples contained within &#96;output_slices&#96;. This needs to be stored separately\\\\\\\\n    /// to be able to handle 0 channel IO for MIDI-only plugins.\\\\\\\\n    num_samples: usize,\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// Contains slices for the plugin's outputs. You can't directly create a nested slice from a\\\\\\\\n    /// pointer to pointers, so this needs to be preallocated in the setup call and kept around\\\\\\\\n    /// between process calls. And because storing a reference to this means a) that you need a lot\\\\\\\\n    /// of lifetime annotations everywhere and b) that at some point you need unsound lifetime casts\\\\\\\\n    /// because this &#96;Buffers&#96; either cannot have the same lifetime as the separately stored output\\\\\\\\n    /// buffers, and it also cannot be stored in a field next to it because that would mean\\\\\\\\n    /// containing mutable references to data stored in a mutex.\\\\\\\\n    output_slices: Vec&lt;&amp;'a mut [f32]&gt;,\\\\\\\\n}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nimpl&lt;'a&gt; Buffer&lt;'a&gt; {\\\\\\\\n    /// Returns the number of samples per channel in this buffer.\\\\\\\\n    #[inline]\\\\\\\\n    pub fn samples(&amp;self) -&gt; usize {\\\\\\\\n        self.num_samples\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// Returns the number of channels in this buffer.\\\\\\\\n    #[inline]\\\\\\\\n    pub fn channels(&amp;self) -&gt; usize {\\\\\\\\n        self.output_slices.len()\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// Returns true if this buffer does not contain any samples.\\\\\\\\n    #[inline]\\\\\\\\n    pub fn is_empty(&amp;self) -&gt; bool {\\\\\\\\n        self.num_samples == 0\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// Obtain the raw audio buffers.\\\\\\\\n    #[inline]\\\\\\\\n    pub fn as_slice(&amp;mut self) -&gt; &amp;mut [&amp;'a mut [f32]] {\\\\\\\\n        &amp;mut self.output_slices\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// The same as [&#96;as_slice()&#96;][Self::as_slice()], but for a non-mutable reference. This is\\\\\\\\n    /// usually not needed.\\\\\\\\n    #[inline]\\\\\\\\n    pub fn as_slice_immutable(&amp;self) -&gt; &amp;[&amp;'a mut [f32]] {\\\\\\\\n        &amp;self.output_slices\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// Iterate over the samples, returning a channel iterator for each sample.\\\\\\\\n    #[inline]\\\\\\\\n    pub fn iter_samples&lt;'slice&gt;(&amp;'slice mut self) -&gt; SamplesIter&lt;'slice, 'a&gt; {\\\\\\\\n        SamplesIter {\\\\\\\\n            buffers: self.output_slices.as_mut_slice(),\\\\\\\\n            current_sample: 0,\\\\\\\\n            samples_end: self.samples(),\\\\\\\\n            _marker: PhantomData,\\\\\\\\n        }\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// Iterate over the buffer in blocks with the specified maximum size. The ideal maximum block\\\\\\\\n    /// size depends on the plugin in question, but 64 or 128 samples works for most plugins. Since\\\\\\\\n    /// the buffer's total size may not be cleanly divisible by the maximum size, the returned\\\\\\\\n    /// buffers may have any size in &#96;[1, max_block_size]&#96;. This is useful when using algorithms\\\\\\\\n    /// that work on entire blocks of audio, like those that would otherwise need to perform\\\\\\\\n    /// expensive per-sample branching or that can use per-sample SIMD as opposed to per-channel\\\\\\\\n    /// SIMD.\\\\\\\\n    ///\\\\\\\\n    /// The parameter smoothers can also produce smoothed values for an entire block using\\\\\\\\n    /// [&#96;Smoother::next_block()&#96;][crate::prelude::Smoother::next_block()].\\\\\\\\n    ///\\\\\\\\n    /// You can use this to obtain block-slices from a buffer so you can pass them to a library:\\\\\\\\n    ///\\\\\\\\n    /// &#96;&#96;&#96;ignore\\\\\\\\n    /// for block in buffer.iter_blocks(128) {\\\\\\\\n    ///     let mut block_channels = block.into_iter();\\\\\\\\n    ///     let stereo_slice = &amp;[\\\\\\\\n    ///         block_channels.next().unwrap(),\\\\\\\\n    ///         block_channels.next().unwrap(),\\\\\\\\n    ///     ];\\\\\\\\n    ///\\\\\\\\n    ///     // Do something cool with &#96;stereo_slice&#96;\\\\\\\\n    /// }\\\\\\\\n    /// &#96;&#96;&#96;&#96;\\\\\\\\n    #[inline]\\\\\\\\n    pub fn iter_blocks&lt;'slice&gt;(&amp;'slice mut self, max_block_size: usize) -&gt; BlocksIter&lt;'slice, 'a&gt; {\\\\\\\\n        BlocksIter {\\\\\\\\n            buffers: self.output_slices.as_mut_slice(),\\\\\\\\n            max_block_size,\\\\\\\\n            current_block_start: 0,\\\\\\\\n            _marker: PhantomData,\\\\\\\\n        }\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// Set the slices in the raw output slice vector. This vector needs to be resized to match the\\\\\\\\n    /// number of output channels during the plugin's initialization. Then during audio processing,\\\\\\\\n    /// these slices should be updated to point to the plugin's audio buffers. The &#96;num_samples&#96;\\\\\\\\n    /// argument should match the length of the inner slices.\\\\\\\\n    ///\\\\\\\\n    /// # Safety\\\\\\\\n    ///\\\\\\\\n    /// The stored slices must point to live data when this object is passed to the plugins' process\\\\\\\\n    /// function. The rest of this object also assumes all channel lengths are equal. Panics will\\\\\\\\n    /// likely occur if this is not the case.\\\\\\\\n    pub unsafe fn set_slices(\\\\\\\\n        &amp;mut self,\\\\\\\\n        num_samples: usize,\\\\\\\\n        update: impl FnOnce(&amp;mut Vec&lt;&amp;'a mut [f32]&gt;),\\\\\\\\n    ) {\\\\\\\\n        self.num_samples = num_samples;\\\\\\\\n        update(&amp;mut self.output_slices);\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n        #[cfg(debug_assertions)]\\\\\\\\n        for slice in &amp;self.output_slices {\\\\\\\\n            nih_debug_assert_eq!(slice.len(), num_samples);\\\\\\\\n        }\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n#[cfg(any(miri, test))]\\\\\\\\nmod miri {\\\\\\\\n    use super::*;\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    #[test]\\\\\\\\n    fn repeated_access() {\\\\\\\\n        let mut real_buffers = vec![vec![0.0; 512]; 2];\\\\\\\\n        let mut buffer = Buffer::default();\\\\\\\\n        unsafe {\\\\\\\\n            buffer.set_slices(512, |output_slices| {\\\\\\\\n                let (first_channel, other_channels) = real_buffers.split_at_mut(1);\\\\\\\\n                *output_slices = vec![&amp;mut first_channel[0], &amp;mut other_channels[0]];\\\\\\\\n            })\\\\\\\\n        };\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n        for samples in buffer.iter_samples() {\\\\\\\\n            for sample in samples {\\\\\\\\n                *sample += 0.001;\\\\\\\\n            }\\\\\\\\n        }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n        for mut samples in buffer.iter_samples() {\\\\\\\\n            for _ in 0..2 {\\\\\\\\n                for sample in samples.iter_mut() {\\\\\\\\n                    *sample += 0.001;\\\\\\\\n                }\\\\\\\\n            }\\\\\\\\n        }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n        assert_eq!(real_buffers[0][0], 0.003);\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    #[test]\\\\\\\\n    fn repeated_slices() {\\\\\\\\n        let mut real_buffers = vec![vec![0.0; 512]; 2];\\\\\\\\n        let mut buffer = Buffer::default();\\\\\\\\n        unsafe {\\\\\\\\n            buffer.set_slices(512, |output_slices| {\\\\\\\\n                let (first_channel, other_channels) = real_buffers.split_at_mut(1);\\\\\\\\n                *output_slices = vec![&amp;mut first_channel[0], &amp;mut other_channels[0]];\\\\\\\\n            })\\\\\\\\n        };\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n        // These iterators should not alias\\\\\\\\n        let mut blocks = buffer.iter_blocks(16);\\\\\\\\n        let (_block1_offset, block1) = blocks.next().unwrap();\\\\\\\\n        let (_block2_offset, block2) = blocks.next().unwrap();\\\\\\\\n        for channel in block1 {\\\\\\\\n            for sample in channel.iter_mut() {\\\\\\\\n                *sample += 0.001;\\\\\\\\n            }\\\\\\\\n        }\\\\\\\\n        for channel in block2 {\\\\\\\\n            for sample in channel.iter_mut() {\\\\\\\\n                *sample += 0.001;\\\\\\\\n            }\\\\\\\\n        }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n        for i in 0..32 {\\\\\\\\n }\\\\\\\\n}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"totalLinesInFile\\\\\\\":202}\\\"},\\\"capabilityType\\\":15}\",\"f3b7d0e5-a4f6-4cc3-be53-6c9810e52537\":\"{\\\"_v\\\":3,\\\"type\\\":2,\\\"approximateLintErrors\\\":[],\\\"lints\\\":[],\\\"codebaseContextChunks\\\":[],\\\"commits\\\":[],\\\"pullRequests\\\":[],\\\"attachedCodeChunks\\\":[],\\\"assistantSuggestedDiffs\\\":[],\\\"gitDiffs\\\":[],\\\"interpreterResults\\\":[],\\\"images\\\":[],\\\"attachedFolders\\\":[],\\\"attachedFoldersNew\\\":[],\\\"bubbleId\\\":\\\"23d6e959-5375-4860-803f-58295d50d1ac\\\",\\\"userResponsesToSuggestedCodeBlocks\\\":[],\\\"suggestedCodeBlocks\\\":[],\\\"diffsForCompressingFiles\\\":[],\\\"relevantFiles\\\":[],\\\"toolResults\\\":[],\\\"notepads\\\":[],\\\"capabilities\\\":[],\\\"multiFileLinterErrors\\\":[],\\\"diffHistories\\\":[],\\\"recentLocationsHistory\\\":[],\\\"recentlyViewedFiles\\\":[],\\\"isAgentic\\\":false,\\\"fileDiffTrajectories\\\":[],\\\"existedSubsequentTerminalCommand\\\":false,\\\"existedPreviousTerminalCommand\\\":false,\\\"docsReferences\\\":[],\\\"webReferences\\\":[],\\\"aiWebSearchResults\\\":[],\\\"requestId\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"attachedFoldersListDirResults\\\":[],\\\"humanChanges\\\":[],\\\"attachedHumanChanges\\\":false,\\\"summarizedComposers\\\":[],\\\"cursorRules\\\":[],\\\"contextPieces\\\":[],\\\"editTrailContexts\\\":[],\\\"allThinkingBlocks\\\":[],\\\"diffsSinceLastApply\\\":[],\\\"deletedFiles\\\":[],\\\"supportedTools\\\":[],\\\"tokenCount\\\":{\\\"inputTokens\\\":0,\\\"outputTokens\\\":0},\\\"attachedFileCodeChunksMetadataOnly\\\":[],\\\"consoleLogs\\\":[],\\\"uiElementPicked\\\":[],\\\"isRefunded\\\":false,\\\"knowledgeItems\\\":[],\\\"documentationSelections\\\":[],\\\"externalLinks\\\":[],\\\"projectLayouts\\\":[],\\\"unifiedMode\\\":2,\\\"capabilityContexts\\\":[],\\\"todos\\\":[],\\\"createdAt\\\":\\\"2026-02-16T20:45:57.858Z\\\",\\\"mcpDescriptors\\\":[],\\\"workspaceUris\\\":[],\\\"conversationState\\\":{\\\"rootPromptMessagesJson\\\":[],\\\"turnsOld\\\" \"{\\\"_v\\\":3,\\\"type\\\":2,\\\"approximateLintErrors\\\":[],\\\"lints\\\":[],\\\"codebaseContextChunks\\\":[],\\\"commits\\\":[],\\\"pullRequests\\\":[],\\\"attachedCodeChunks\\\":[],\\\"assistantSuggestedDiffs\\\":[],\\\"gitDiffs\\\":[],\\\"interpreterResults\\\":[],\\\"images\\\":[],\\\"attachedFolders\\\":[],\\\"attachedFoldersNew\\\":[],\\\"bubbleId\\\":\\\"f875e795-efbb-4c27-a10b-ee5eba9751ff\\\",\\\"userResponsesToSuggestedCodeBlocks\\\":[],\\\"suggestedCodeBlocks\\\":[],\\\"diffsForCompressingFiles\\\":[],\\\"relevantFiles\\\":[],\\\"toolResults\\\":[],\\\"notepads\\\":[],\\\"capabilities\\\":[],\\\"multiFileLinterErrors\\\":[],\\\"diffHistories\\\":[],\\\"recentLocationsHistory\\\":[],\\\"recentlyViewedFiles\\\":[],\\\"isAgentic\\\":false,\\\"fileDiffTrajectories\\\":[],\\\"existedSubsequentTerminalCommand\\\":false,\\\"existedPreviousTerminalCommand\\\":false,\\\"docsReferences\\\":[],\\\"webReferences\\\":[],\\\"aiWebSearchResults\\\":[],\\\"requestId\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"attachedFoldersListDirResults\\\":[],\\\"humanChanges\\\":[],\\\"attachedHumanChanges\\\":false,\\\"summarizedComposers\\\":[],\\\"cursorRules\\\":[],\\\"contextPieces\\\":[],\\\"editTrailContexts\\\":[],\\\"allThinkingBlocks\\\":[],\\\"diffsSinceLastApply\\\":[],\\\"deletedFiles\\\":[],\\\"supportedTools\\\":[],\\\"tokenCount\\\":{\\\"inputTokens\\\":0,\\\"outputTokens\\\":0},\\\"attachedFileCodeChunksMetadataOnly\\\":[],\\\"consoleLogs\\\":[],\\\"uiElementPicked\\\":[],\\\"isRefunded\\\":false,\\\"knowledgeItems\\\":[],\\\"documentationSelections\\\":[],\\\"externalLinks\\\":[],\\\"projectLayouts\\\":[],\\\"unifiedMode\\\":2,\\\"capabilityContexts\\\":[],\\\"todos\\\":[],\\\"createdAt\\\":\\\"2026-02-16T20:45:57.858Z\\\",\\\"mcpDescriptors\\\":[],\\\"workspaceUris\\\":[],\\\"conversationState\\\":{\\\"rootPromptMessagesJson\\\":[],\\\"turnsOld\\\":[],\\\"todos\\\":[],\\\"pendingToolCalls\\\":[],\\\"turns\\\":[],\\\"previousWorkspaceUris\\\":[],\\\"fileStates\\\":{},\\\"summaryArchives\\\":[],\\\"turnTimings\\\":[],\\\"fileStatesV2\\\":{},\\\"subagentStates\\\":{},\\\"selfSummaryCount\\\":0,\\\"readPaths\\\":[]},\\\"text\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"toolFormerData\\\":{\\\"toolCallId\\\":\\\"tool_a88efe1d-2ebd-4e20-a53a-934e943d397\\\",\\\"toolIndex\\\":0,\\\"modelCallId\\\":\\\"tool_a88efe1d-2ebd-4e20-a53a-934e943d397\\\",\\\"status\\\":\\\"completed\\\",\\\"name\\\":\\\"read_file_v2\\\",\\\"rawArgs\\\":\\\"{\\\\\\\"path\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"/Users/b/code/z-plug/nih-plug/src/audio_setup.rs\\\\\\\"}\\\",\\\"tool\\\":40,\\\"params\\\":\\\"{\\\\\\\"targetFile\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"/Users/b/code/z-plug/nih-plug/src/audio_setup.rs\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"charsLimit\\\\\\\":1000000,\\\\\\\"effectiveUri\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"/Users/b/code/z-plug/nih-plug/src/audio_setup.rs\\\\\\\"}\\\",\\\"result\\\":\\\"{\\\\\\\"contents\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"//! Types and definitions surrounding a plugin's audio IO setup.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nuse std::num::NonZeroU32;\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nuse crate::prelude::Buffer;\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n/// A description of a plugin's audio IO configuration. The [&#96;Plugin&#96;][crate::prelude::Plugin]\\\\\\\\n/// defines a list of supported audio IO configs, with the first one acting as the default layout.\\\\\\\\n/// Depending on the plugin API, the host may pick a different configuration from the list and use\\\\\\\\n/// that instead. The final chosen configuration is passed as an argument to the\\\\\\\\n/// [&#96;Plugin::initialize()&#96;][crate::prelude::Plugin::initialize] function so the plugin can allocate\\\\\\\\n/// its data structures based on the number of audio channels it needs to process.\\\\\\\\n#[derive(Debug, Default, Clone, Copy, PartialEq, Eq, Hash)]\\\\\\\\npub struct AudioIOLayout {\\\\\\\\n    /// The number of main input channels for the plugin, if it has a main input port. This can be\\\\\\\\n    /// set to &#96;None&#96; if the plugin does not have one.\\\\\\\\n    pub main_input_channels: Option&lt;NonZeroU32&gt;,\\\\\\\\n    /// The number of main output channels for the plugin, if it has a main output port. This can be\\\\\\\\n    /// set to &#96;None&#96; if the plugin does not have one.\\\\\\\\n    pub main_output_channels: Option&lt;NonZeroU32&gt;,\\\\\\\\n    /// The plugin's additional sidechain inputs, if it has any. Use the [&#96;new_nonzero_u32()&#96;]\\\\\\\\n    /// function to construct these values until const &#96;Option::unwrap()&#96; gets stabilized\\\\\\\\n    /// (&lt;https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/67441&gt;).\\\\\\\\n    pub aux_input_ports: &amp;'static [NonZeroU32],\\\\\\\\n    /// The plugin's additional outputs, if it has any. Use the [&#96;new_nonzero_u32()&#96;] function to\\\\\\\\n    /// construct these values until const &#96;Option::unwrap()&#96; gets stabilized\\\\\\\\n    /// (&lt;https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/67441&gt;).\\\\\\\\n    pub aux_output_ports: &amp;'static [NonZeroU32],\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// Optional names for the audio ports. Defining these can be useful for plugins with multiple\\\\\\\\n    /// output and input ports.\\\\\\\\n    pub names: PortNames,\\\\\\\\n}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n/// Construct a &#96;NonZeroU32&#96; value at compile time. Equivalent to &#96;NonZeroU32::new(n).unwrap()&#96;.\\\\\\\\npub const fn new_nonzero_u32(n: u32) -&gt; NonZeroU32 {\\\\\\\\n    match NonZeroU32::new(n) {\\\\\\\\n        Some(n) =&gt; n,\\\\\\\\n        None =&gt; panic!(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"'new_nonzero_u32()' called with a zero value\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"),\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n/// Contains auxiliary (sidechain) input and output buffers for a process call.\\\\\\\\npub struct AuxiliaryBuffers&lt;'a&gt; {\\\\\\\\n    /// Buffers for all auxiliary (sidechain) inputs defined for this plugin. The data in these\\\\\\\\n    /// buffers can safely be overwritten. Auxiliary inputs can be defined using the\\\\\\\\n    /// [&#96;AudioIOLayout::aux_input_ports&#96;] field.\\\\\\\\n    pub inputs: &amp;'a mut [Buffer&lt;'a&gt;],\\\\\\\\n    /// Buffers for all auxiliary outputs defined for this plugin. Auxiliary outputs can be defined using the\\\\\\\\n    /// [&#96;AudioIOLayout::aux_output_ports&#96;] field.\\\\\\\\n    pub outputs: &amp;'a mut [Buffer&lt;'a&gt;],\\\\\\\\n}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n/// Contains names for the ports defined in an &#96;AudioIOLayout&#96;. Setting these is optional, but it\\\\\\\\n/// makes working with multi-output plugins much more convenient.\\\\\\\\n///\\\\\\\\n/// All of these names should start with a capital letter to be consistent with automatically\\\\\\\\n/// generated names.\\\\\\\\n#[derive(Debug, Default, Clone, Copy, PartialEq, Eq, Hash)]\\\\\\\\npub struct PortNames {\\\\\\\\n    /// The name for the audio IO layout as a whole. Useful when a plugin has multiple distinct\\\\\\\\n    /// layouts. Will be generated if not set.\\\\\\\\n    pub layout: Option&lt;&amp;'static str&gt;,\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// The name for the main input port. Will be generated if not set.\\\\\\\\n    pub main_input: Option&lt;&amp;'static str&gt;,\\\\\\\\n    /// The name for the main output port. Will be generated if not set.\\\\\\\\n    pub main_output: Option&lt;&amp;'static str&gt;,\\\\\\\\n    /// Names for auxiliary (sidechain) input ports. Will be generated if not set or if this slice\\\\\\\\n    /// does not contain enough names.\\\\\\\\n    pub aux_inputs: &amp;'static [&amp;'static str],\\\\\\\\n    /// Names for auxiliary output ports. Will be generated if not set or if this slice does not\\\\\\\\n    /// contain enough names.\\\\\\\\n    pub aux_outputs: &amp;'static [&amp;'static str],\\\\\\\\n}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n/// Configuration for (the host's) audio buffers.\\\\\\\\n#[derive(Debug, Clone, Copy, PartialEq)]\\\\\\\\npub struct BufferConfig {\\\\\\\\n    /// The current sample rate.\\\\\\\\n    pub sample_rate: f32,\\\\\\\\n    /// The minimum buffer size the host will use. This may not be set.\\\\\\\\n    pub min_buffer_size: Option&lt;u32&gt;,\\\\\\\\n    /// The maximum buffer size the host will use. The plugin should be able to accept variable\\\\\\\\n    /// sized buffers up to this size, or between the minimum and the maximum buffer size if both\\\\\\\\n    /// are set.\\\\\\\\n    pub max_buffer_size: u32,\\\\\\\\n    /// The current processing mode. The host will reinitialize the plugin any time this changes.\\\\\\\\n    pub process_mode: ProcessMode,\\\\\\\\n}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n/// The plugin's current processing mode. Exposed through [&#96;BufferConfig::process_mode&#96;]. The host\\\\\\\\n/// will reinitialize the plugin whenever this changes.\\\\\\\\n#[derive(Debug, Clone, Copy, PartialEq, Eq)]\\\\\\\\npub enum ProcessMode {\\\\\\\\n    /// The plugin is processing audio in real time at a fixed rate.\\\\\\\\n    Realtime,\\\\\\\\n    /// The plugin is processing audio at a real time-like pace, but at irregular intervals. The\\\\\\\\n    /// host may do this to process audio ahead of time to loosen realtime constraints and to reduce\\\\\\\\n    /// the chance of xruns happening. This is only used by VST3.\\\\\\\\n    Buffered,\\\\\\\\n    /// The plugin is rendering audio offline, potentially faster than realtime ('freewheeling').\\\\\\\\n    /// The host will continuously call the process function back to back until all audio has been\\\\\\\\n    /// processed.\\\\\\\\n    Offline,\\\\\\\\n}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nimpl AudioIOLayout {\\\\\\\\n    /// [&#96;AudioIOLayout::default()&#96;], but as a const function. Used when initializing\\\\\\\\n    /// &#96;Plugin::AUDIO_IO_LAYOUTS&#96;. (&lt;https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/67792&gt;)\\\\\\\\n    pub const fn const_default() -&gt; Self {\\\\\\\\n        Self {\\\\\\\\n            main_input_channels: None,\\\\\\\\n            main_output_channels: None,\\\\\\\\n            aux_input_ports: &amp;[],\\\\\\\\n            aux_output_ports: &amp;[],\\\\\\\\n            names: PortNames::const_default(),\\\\\\\\n        }\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// A descriptive name for the layout. This is taken from &#96;PortNames::layout&#96; if set. Otherwise\\\\\\\\n    /// it is generated based on the layout.\\\\\\\\n    pub fn name(&amp;self) -&gt; String {\\\\\\\\n        if let Some(name) = self.names.layout {\\\\\\\\n            return name.to_owned();\\\\\\\\n        }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n        // If the name is not set then we'll try to come up with something descriptive\\\\\\\\n        match (\\\\\\\\n            self.main_input_channels\\\\\\\\n                .map(NonZeroU32::get)\\\\\\\\n                .unwrap_or_default(),\\\\\\\\n            self.main_output_channels\\\\\\\\n                .map(NonZeroU32::get)\\\\\\\\n                .unwrap_or_default(),\\\\\\\\n            self.aux_input_ports.len(),\\\\\\\\n            self.aux_output_ports.len(),\\\\\\\\n        ) {\\\\\\\\n            (0, 0, 0, 0) =&gt; String::from(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"Empty\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"),\\\\\\\\n            (_, 1, 0, _) | (1, 0, _, _) =&gt; String::from(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"Mono\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"),\\\\\\\\n            (_, 2, 0, _) | (2, 0, _, _) =&gt; String::from(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"Stereo\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"),\\\\\\\\n            (_, 1, _, _) =&gt; String::from(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"Mono with sidechain\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"),\\\\\\\\n            (_, 2, _, _) =&gt; String::from(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"Stereo with sidechain\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"),\\\\\\\\n            // These probably, hopefully won't occur\\\\\\\\n            (i, o, 0, 0) =&gt; format!(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"{i} inputs, {o} outputs\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"),\\\\\\\\n            (i, o, _, 0) =&gt; format!(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"{i} inputs, {o} outputs, with sidechain\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"),\\\\\\\\n            // And these don't make much sense, suggestions for something better are welcome\\\\\\\\n            (i, o, 0, aux_o) =&gt; format!(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"{i} inputs, {o}*{} outputs\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", aux_o + 1),\\\\\\\\n            (i, o, aux_i, aux_o) =&gt; format!(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"{i}*{} inputs, {o}*{} outputs\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", aux_i + 1, aux_o + 1),\\\\\\\\n        }\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// The name for the main input port. Either generated or taken from the &#96;names&#96; field.\\\\\\\\n    pub fn main_input_name(&amp;self) -&gt; String {\\\\\\\\n        self.names.main_input.unwrap_or(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"Input\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\").to_owned()\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// The name for the main output port. Either generated or taken from the &#96;names&#96; field.\\\\\\\\n    pub fn main_output_name(&amp;self) -&gt; String {\\\\\\\\n        self.names.main_input.unwrap_or(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"Output\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\").to_owned()\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// The name for the auxiliary input port with the given index. Either generated or taken from\\\\\\\\n    /// the &#96;names&#96; field.\\\\\\\\n    pub fn aux_input_name(&amp;self, idx: usize) -&gt; Option&lt;String&gt; {\\\\\\\\n        if idx &gt;= self.aux_input_ports.len() {\\\\\\\\n            None\\\\\\\\n        } else {\\\\\\\\n            match self.names.aux_inputs.get(idx) {\\\\\\\\n                Some(name) =&gt; Some(String::from(*name)),\\\\\\\\n                None if self.aux_input_ports.len() == 1 =&gt; Some(String::from(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"Sidechain Input\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\")),\\\\\\\\n                None =&gt; Some(format!(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"Sidechain Input {}\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", idx + 1)),\\\\\\\\n            }\\\\\\\\n        }\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// The name for the auxiliary output port with the given index. Either generated or taken from\\\\\\\\n    /// the &#96;names&#96; field.\\\\\\\\n    pub fn aux_output_name(&amp;self, idx: usize) -&gt; Option&lt;String&gt; {\\\\\\\\n        if idx &gt;= self.aux_output_ports.len() {\\\\\\\\n            None\\\\\\\\n        } else {\\\\\\\\n            match self.names.aux_outputs.get(idx) {\\\\\\\\n                Some(name) =&gt; Some(String::from(*name)),\\\\\\\\n                None if self.aux_output_ports.len() == 1 =&gt; Some(String::from(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"Auxiliary Output\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\")),\\\\\\\\n                None =&gt; Some(format!(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"Auxiliary Output {}\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", idx + 1)),\\\\\\\\n            }\\\\\\\\n        }\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nimpl PortNames {\\\\\\\\n    /// [&#96;PortNames::default()&#96;], but as a const function. Used when initializing\\\\\\\\n    /// &#96;Plugin::AUDIO_IO_LAYOUTS&#96;. Per-sample per-channel iterators.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nuse std::marker::PhantomData;\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n#[cfg(feature = \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"simd\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\")]\\\\\\\\nuse std::simd::{LaneCount, Simd, SupportedLaneCount};\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n/// An iterator over all samples in a buffer or block, yielding iterators over each channel for\\\\\\\\n/// every sample. This iteration order offers good cache locality for per-sample access.\\\\\\\\npub struct SamplesIter&lt;'slice, 'sample: 'slice&gt; {\\\\\\\\n    /// The raw output buffers.\\\\\\\\n    pub(super) buffers: *mut [&amp;'sample mut [f32]],\\\\\\\\n    pub(super) current_sample: usize,\\\\\\\\n    /// The last sample index to iterate over plus one. Would be equal to &#96;buffers.len()&#96; when\\\\\\\\n    /// iterating over an entire buffer, but this can also be used to iterate over smaller blocks in\\\\\\\\n    /// a similar fashion.\\\\\\\\n    pub(super) samples_end: usize,\\\\\\\\n    pub(super) _marker: PhantomData&lt;&amp;'slice mut [&amp;'sample mut [f32]]&gt;,\\\\\\\\n}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n/// Can construct iterators over actual iterator over the channel data for a sample, yielded by\\\\\\\\n/// [&#96;SamplesIter&#96;]. Can be turned into an iterator, or [&#96;ChannelSamples::iter_mut()&#96;] can be used\\\\\\\\n/// to iterate over the channel data multiple times, or more efficiently you can use\\\\\\\\n/// [&#96;ChannelSamples::get_unchecked_mut()&#96;] to do the same thing.\\\\\\\\npub struct ChannelSamples&lt;'slice, 'sample: 'slice&gt; {\\\\\\\\n    /// The raw output buffers.\\\\\\\\n    pub(self) buffers: *mut [&amp;'sample mut [f32]],\\\\\\\\n    pub(self) current_sample: usize,\\\\\\\\n    pub(self) _marker: PhantomData&lt;&amp;'slice mut [&amp;'sample mut [f32]]&gt;,\\\\\\\\n}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n/// The actual iterator over the channel data for a sample, yielded by [&#96;ChannelSamples&#96;].\\\\\\\\npub struct ChannelSamplesIter&lt;'slice, 'sample: 'slice&gt; {\\\\\\\\n    /// The raw output buffers.\\\\\\\\n    pub(self) buffers: *mut [&amp;'sample mut [f32]],\\\\\\\\n    pub(self) current_sample: usize,\\\\\\\\n    pub(self) current_channel: usize,\\\\\\\\n    pub(self) _marker: PhantomData&lt;&amp;'slice mut [&amp;'sample mut [f32]]&gt;,\\\\\\\\n}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nimpl&lt;'slice, 'sample&gt; Iterator for SamplesIter&lt;'slice, 'sample&gt; {\\\\\\\\n    type Item = ChannelSamples&lt;'slice, 'sample&gt;;\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    #[inline]\\\\\\\\n    fn next(&amp;mut self) -&gt; Option&lt;Self::Item&gt; {\\\\\\\\n        // This can iterate over both the entire buffer or over a smaller sample slice of it\\\\\\\\n        if self.current_sample &lt; self.samples_end {\\\\\\\\n            let channels = ChannelSamples {\\\\\\\\n                buffers: self.buffers,\\\\\\\\n                current_sample: self.current_sample,\\\\\\\\n                _marker: self._marker,\\\\\\\\n            };\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n            self.current_sample += 1;\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n            Some(channels)\\\\\\\\n        } else {\\\\\\\\n            None\\\\\\\\n        }\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    #[inline]\\\\\\\\n    fn size_hint(&amp;self) -&gt; (usize, Option&lt;usize&gt;) {\\\\\\\\n        let remaining = self.samples_end - self.current_sample;\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n        (remaining, Some(remaining))\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nimpl&lt;'slice, 'sample&gt; IntoIterator for ChannelSamples&lt;'slice, 'sample&gt; {\\\\\\\\n    type Item = &amp;'sample mut f32;\\\\\\\\n    type IntoIter = ChannelSamplesIter&lt;'slice, 'sample&gt;;\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    #[inline]\\\\\\\\n    fn into_iter(self) -&gt; Self::IntoIter {\\\\\\\\n        ChannelSamplesIter {\\\\\\\\n            buffers: self.buffers,\\\\\\\\n            current_sample: self.current_sample,\\\\\\\\n            current_channel: 0,\\\\\\\\n            _marker: self._marker,\\\\\\\\n        }\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nimpl&lt;'slice, 'sample&gt; Iterator for ChannelSamplesIter&lt;'slice, 'sample&gt; {\\\\\\\\n    type Item = &amp;'sample mut f32;\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    #[inline]\\\\\\\\n    fn next(&amp;mut self) -&gt; Option&lt;Self::Item&gt; {\\\\\\\\n        if self.current_channel &lt; unsafe { (&amp;(*self.buffers)).len() } {\\\\\\\\n            // SAFETY: These bounds have already been checked\\\\\\\\n            // SAFETY: It is also not possible to have multiple mutable references to the same\\\\\\\\n            // sample at the same time\\\\\\\\n            let sample = unsafe {\\\\\\\\n                (&amp;mut (*self.buffers))\\\\\\\\n                    .get_unchecked_mut(self.current_channel)\\\\\\\\n                    .get_unchecked_mut(self.current_sample)\\\\\\\\n            };\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n            self.current_channel += 1;\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n            Some(sample)\\\\\\\\n        } else {\\\\\\\\n            None\\\\\\\\n        }\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    #[inline]\\\\\\\\n    fn size_hint(&amp;self) -&gt; (usize, Option&lt;usize&gt;) {\\\\\\\\n        let remaining = unsafe { (&amp;(*self.buffers)).len() } - self.current_channel;\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n        (remaining, Some(remaining))\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nimpl ExactSizeIterator for SamplesIter&lt;'_, '_&gt; {}\\\\\\\\nimpl ExactSizeIterator for ChannelSamplesIter&lt;'_, '_&gt; {}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nimpl&lt;'slice, 'sample&gt; ChannelSamples&lt;'slice, 'sample&gt; {\\\\\\\\n    /// Get the number of channels.\\\\\\\\n    #[allow(clippy::len_without_is_empty)]\\\\\\\\n    #[inline]\\\\\\\\n    pub fn len(&amp;self) -&gt; usize {\\\\\\\\n        unsafe { (&amp;(*self.buffers)).len() }\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// A resetting iterator. This lets you iterate over the same channels multiple times. Otherwise\\\\\\\\n    /// you don't need to use this function as [&#96;ChannelSamples&#96;] already implements\\\\\\\\n    /// [&#96;IntoIterator&#96;].\\\\\\\\n    #[inline]\\\\\\\\n    pub fn iter_mut(&amp;mut self) -&gt; ChannelSamplesIter&lt;'slice, 'sample&gt; {\\\\\\\\n        ChannelSamplesIter {\\\\\\\\n            buffers: self.buffers,\\\\\\\\n            current_sample: self.current_sample,\\\\\\\\n            current_channel: 0,\\\\\\\\n            _marker: self._marker,\\\\\\\\n        }\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// Access a sample by index. Useful when you would otherwise iterate over this 'Channels'\\\\\\\\n    /// iterator multiple times.\\\\\\\\n    #[inline]\\\\\\\\n    pub fn get_mut(&amp;mut self, channel_index: usize) -&gt; Option&lt;&amp;mut f32&gt; {\\\\\\\\n        // SAFETY: The sample bound has already been checked\\\\\\\\n        unsafe {\\\\\\\\n            Some(\\\\\\\\n                (&amp;mut (*self.buffers))\\\\\\\\n                    .get_mut(channel_index)?\\\\\\\\n                    .get_unchecked_mut(self.current_sample),\\\\\\\\n            )\\\\\\\\n        }\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// The same as [&#96;get_mut()&#96;][Self::get_mut()], but without any bounds checking.\\\\\\\\n    ///\\\\\\\\n    /// # Safety\\\\\\\\n    ///\\\\\\\\n    /// &#96;channel_index&#96; must be in the range &#96;0..Self::len()&#96;.\\\\\\\\n    #[inline]\\\\\\\\n    pub unsafe fn get_unchecked_mut(&amp;mut self, channel_index: usize) -&gt; &amp;mut f32 {\\\\\\\\n        (&amp;mut (*self.buffers))\\\\\\\\n            .get_unchecked_mut(channel_index)\\\\\\\\n            .get_unchecked_mut(self.current_sample)\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// Get a SIMD vector containing the channel data for this buffer. If &#96;LANES &gt; channels.len()&#96;\\\\\\\\n    /// then this will be padded with zeroes. If &#96;LANES &lt; channels.len()&#96; then this won't contain\\\\\\\\n    /// all values.\\\\\\\\n    #[cfg(feature = \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"simd\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\")]\\\\\\\\n    #[inline]\\\\\\\\n    pub fn to_simd&lt;const LANES: usize&gt;(&amp;self) -&gt; Simd&lt;f32, LANES&gt;\\\\\\\\n    where\\\\\\\\n        LaneCount&lt;LANES&gt;: SupportedLaneCount,\\\\\\\\n    {\\\\\\\\n        let used_lanes = self.len().max(LANES);\\\\\\\\n        let mut values = [0.0; LANES];\\\\\\\\n        for (channel_idx, value) in values.iter_mut().enumerate().take(used_lanes) {\\\\\\\\n            *value = unsafe {\\\\\\\\n                *(&amp;(*self.buffers))\\\\\\\\n                    .get_unchecked(channel_idx)\\\\\\\\n                    .get_unchecked(self.current_sample)\\\\\\\\n            };\\\\\\\\n        }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n        Simd::from_array(values)\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// Get a SIMD vector containing the channel data for this buffer. Will always read exactly\\\\\\\\n    /// &#96;LANES&#96; channels.\\\\\\\\n    ///\\\\\\\\n    /// # Safety\\\\\\\\n    ///\\\\\\\\n    /// Undefined behavior if &#96;LANES &gt; channels.len()&#96;.\\\\\\\\n    #[cfg(feature = \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"simd\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\")]\\\\\\\\n    #[inline]\\\\\\\\n    pub unsafe fn to_simd_unchecked&lt;const LANES: usize&gt;(&amp;self) -&gt; Simd&lt;f32, LANES&gt;\\\\\\\\n    where\\\\\\\\n        LaneCount&lt;LANES&gt;: SupportedLaneCount,\\\\\\\\n    {\\\\\\\\n        let mut values = [0.0; LANES];\\\\\\\\n        for (channel_idx, value) in values.iter_mut().enumerate() {\\\\\\\\n            *value = *(&amp;(*self.buffers))\\\\\\\\n                .get_unchecked(channel_idx)\\\\\\\\n                .get_unchecked(self.current_sample);\\\\\\\\n        }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n        Simd::from_array(values)\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// Write data from a SIMD vector to this sample's channel data. This takes the padding added by\\\\\\\\n    /// [&#96;to_simd()&#96;][Self::to_simd()] into account.\\\\\\\\n    #[cfg(feature = \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"simd\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\")]\\\\\\\\n    #[allow(clippy::wrong_self_convention)]\\\\\\\\n    #[inline]\\\\\\\\n    pub fn from_simd&lt;const LANES: usize&gt;(&amp;mut self, vector: Simd&lt;f32, LANES&gt;)\\\\\\\\n    where\\\\\\\\n        LaneCount&lt;LANES&gt;: SupportedLaneCount,\\\\\\\\n    {\\\\\\\\n        let used_lanes = self.len().max(LANES);\\\\\\\\n        let values = vector.to_array();\\\\\\\\n        for (channel_idx, value) in values.into_iter().enumerate().take(used_lanes) {\\\\\\\\n            *unsafe {\\\\\\\\n                (&amp;mut (*self.buffers))\\\\\\\\n                    .get_unchecked_mut(channel_idx)\\\\\\\\n                    .get_unchecked_mut(self.current_sample)\\\\\\\\n            } = value;\\\\\\\\n        }\\\\\\\\n    }\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    /// Write data from a SIMD vector to this sample's channel data. This assumes &#96;LANES&#96; matches\\\\\\\\n    /// exactly with the number of channels in the buffer.\\\\\\\\n    ///\\\\\\\\n    /// # Safety\\\\\\\\n    ///\\\\\\\\n    /// Undefined behavior if &#96;LANES &gt; channels.len()&#96;.\\\\\\\\n    #[cfg(feature = \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"simd\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\")]\\\\\\\\n    #[allow(clippy::wrong_self_convention)]\\\\\\\\n    #[inline]\\\\\\\\n    pub unsafe fn from_simd_unchecked&lt;const LANES: usize&gt;(&amp;mut self, vector: Simd&lt;f32, LANES&gt;)\\\\\\\\n    where\\\\\\\\n        LaneCount&lt;LANES&gt;: SupportedLaneCount,\\\\\\\\n    {\\\\\\\\n        let values = vector.to_array();\\\\\\\\n        for (channel_idx, value) in values.into_iter().enumerate() {\\\\\\\\n            *(&amp;mut (*self.buffers))\\\\\\\\n &#96;getTailSamples&#96;\\\\n\\\\n---\\\\n\\\\n## Key Differences for Framework Abstraction\\\\n\\\\n1. Event systems:\\\\n   - CLAP: Tagged union events with a common &#96;Header&#96;; function-pointer-based &#96;InputEvents&#96;/&#96;OutputEvents&#96;\\\\n   - VST3: &#96;Event&#96; union; COM &#96;IEventList&#96; interface\\\\n\\\\n2. Audio buffers:\\\\n   - CLAP: &#96;AudioBuffer&#96; with optional &#96;data32&#96;/&#96;data64&#96;, &#96;constant_mask&#96;\\\\n   - VST3: &#96;AudioBusBuffers&#96; with separate 32/64-bit arrays, &#96;silence_flags&#96;\\\\n\\\\n3. Process context:\\\\n   - CLAP: Optional &#96;transport&#96; pointer with beat/second time\\\\n   - VST3: &#96;ProcessContext&#96; with flags, sample/music time, tempo, time signature\\\\n\\\\n4. Parameter changes:\\\\n   - CLAP: Events (&#96;ParamValue&#96;, &#96;ParamMod&#96;) in the event stream\\\\n   - VST3: Separate &#96;IParameterChanges&#96; interface\\\\n\\\\n5. Sample-accurate timing:\\\\n   - CLAP: &#96;sample_offset&#96; in event &#96;Header&#96;\\\\n   - VST3: &#96;sample_offset&#96; in &#96;Event&#96;\\\\n\\\\nThe framework core should abstract these <think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
Now I have a complete picture. Let me create the plan. The framework core (section 2.2) needs the following files in `src/core/`:

1. `plugin.zig` - PluginInterface, comptime validation, ProcessStatus
2. `params.zig` - Parameter declaration types (FloatParam, IntParam, BoolParam, EnumParam), ParamFlags, ranges, smoothing
3. `buffer.zig` - Buffer abstraction with per-sample, per-block, and raw slice iterators
4. `events.zig` - NoteEvent tagged union, MidiConfig


5. `state.zig` - State save/load interface
6. `audio_layout.zig` - AudioIOLayout, BufferConfig, ProcessMode, PortNames, AuxiliaryBuffers, ProcessContext

Then I'll update `root.zig` to re-export everything as the public API. For `plugin.zig`, I'm using comptime duck-typing where the plugin author defines a struct with specific declarations that `PluginInterface` validates and wraps, similar to how `std.mem.Allocator` works in Zig.

For `params.zig`, I need comptime-friendly parameter types using tagged unions or structs with comptime fields since nih-plug relies on Rust traits with associated types. The `buffer.zig` module wraps `[][]f32` with per-sample and per-block iterators without copying data. The `events.zig` file defines a NoteEvent tagged union covering MIDI and note events supported by both CLAP and VST3. For state management, I'm using Reader/Writer based save/load with Zig 0.15's new I/O interfaces. The `audio_layout.zig` module defines AudioIOLayout, BufferConfig, ProcessMode, and related types, while ProcessContext provides transport information and other context during audio processing.

Now I'm ready to write out the implementation plan.</details></think>

The next step is to build &#96;src/core/&#96; -- the API-agnostic framework layer that plugin authors code against. (BPM)\n  - &#96;time_sig_numerator: ?i32&#96;, &#96;time_sig_denominator: ?i32&#96;\n  - &#96;pos_samples: ?i64&#96;\n  - &#96;pos_beats: ?f64&#96; (quarter notes)\n  - &#96;bar_start_beats: ?f64&#96;\n  - &#96;loop_start_beats: ?f64&#96;, &#96;loop_end_beats: ?f64&#96;\n\n---\n\n### 2. &#96;src/core/events.zig&#96; -- Unified Note/MIDI Event System\n\nA single tagged union that both CLAP and VST3 wrappers will translate to/from.\n\n- **&#96;NoteEvent&#96;** -- &#96;union(enum)&#96; with variants:\n  - &#96;note_on: NoteData&#96; -- velocity: &#96;f32&#96; (0..1)\n  - &#96;note_off: NoteData&#96;\n  - &#96;choke: NoteData&#96; -- abrupt stop (no release)\n  - &#96;voice_terminated: NoteData&#96; -- voice finished naturally (output only)\n  - &#96;poly_pressure: PolyValueData&#96; -- per-note aftertouch\n  - &#96;poly_tuning: PolyValueData&#96;\n  - &#96;poly_vibrato: PolyValueData&#96;\n  - &#96;poly_expression: PolyValueData&#96;\n  - &#96;poly_brightness: PolyValueData&#96;\n  - &#96;poly_volume: PolyValueData&#96;\n  - &#96;poly_pan: PolyValueData&#96;\n  - &#96;midi_cc: MidiCCData&#96; -- sample offset in current buffer\n  - &#96;voice_id: ?i32&#96;\n  - &#96;channel: u8&#96;\n  - &#96;note: u8&#96; -- MIDI note number (0-127)\n  - &#96;velocity: f32&#96;\n\n- **&#96;PolyValueData&#96;**:\n  - &#96;timing: u32&#96;, &#96;voice_id: ?i32&#96;, &#96;channel: u8&#96;, &#96;note: u8&#96;, &#96;value: f32&#96;\n\n- **&#96;MidiCCData&#96;**:\n  - &#96;timing: u32&#96;, &#96;channel: u8&#96;, &#96;cc: u8&#96;, &#96;value: f32&#96;\n\n- **&#96;MidiChannelData&#96;**:\n  - &#96;timing: u32&#96;, &#96;channel: u8&#96;, &#96;value: f32&#96;\n\n- **&#96;MidiProgramData&#96;**:\n  - &#96;timing: u32&#96;, &#96;channel: u8&#96;, &#96;program: u8&#96;\n\n- Helper methods on &#96;NoteEvent&#96;:\n  - &#96;pub fn timing(self) u32&#96; -- extract timing from any variant\n  - &#96;pub fn channel(self) ?u8&#96;\n  - &#96;pub fn voiceId(self) ?i32&#96;\n\n---\n\n### 3. &#96;src/core/params.zig&#96; -- Comptime Parameter System\n\nParameters are declared as comptime data. Plugin authors define a &#96;params&#96; array of &#96;Param&#96; structs.\n\n- **&#96;FloatRange&#96;**:\n  - &#96;min: f32&#96;, &#96;max: f32&#96;\n  - &#96;pub fn normalize(self, plain: f32) f32&#96;\n  - &#96;pub fn unnormalize(self, normalized: f32) f32&#96;\n  - &#96;pub fn clamp(self, value: f32) f32&#96;\n\n- **&#96;IntRange&#96;**:\n  - &#96;min: i32&#96;, &#96;max: i32&#96;\n  - &#96;pub fn normalize/unnormalize/clamp&#96; (similar)\n\n- **&#96;ParamFlags&#96;** -- packed struct:\n  - &#96;automatable: bool = true&#96;\n  - &#96;modulatable: bool = false&#96;\n  - &#96;hidden: bool = false&#96;\n  - &#96;bypass: bool = false&#96;\n  - &#96;is_stepped: bool = false&#96;\n\n- **&#96;Param&#96;** -- tagged union for comptime parameter declaration:\n  - &#96;float: FloatParam&#96;\n  - &#96;int: IntParam&#96;\n  - &#96;boolean: BoolParam&#96;\n  - &#96;choice: ChoiceParam&#96; -- enum-backed parameter\n\n- **&#96;FloatParam&#96;**:\n  - &#96;name: [:0]const u8&#96;\n  - &#96;id: [:0]const u8&#96; -- stable string ID (hashed for VST3 ParamID)\n  - &#96;default: f32&#96;\n  - &#96;range: FloatRange&#96;\n  - &#96;step_size: ?f32 = null&#96;\n  - &#96;unit: [:0]const u8 = \"\"&#96;  (e.g., \"dB\", \"Hz\", \"%\")\n  - &#96;flags: ParamFlags = .{}&#96;\n\n- **&#96;IntParam&#96;**: similar but &#96;i32&#96; values and &#96;IntRange&#96;\n\n- **&#96;BoolParam&#96;**:\n  - &#96;name: [:0]const u8&#96;, &#96;id: [:0]const u8&#96;, &#96;default: bool&#96;, &#96;flags: ParamFlags = .{}&#96;\n\n- **&#96;ChoiceParam&#96;**:\n  - &#96;name: [:0]const u8&#96;, &#96;id: [:0]const u8&#96;, &#96;default: u32&#96; (index), &#96;labels: []const [:0]const u8&#96;, &#96;flags: ParamFlags = .{}&#96;\n\n- **&#96;ParamLayout&#96;** -- comptime-generated metadata (created by the framework from the param array):\n  - &#96;params: []const Param&#96;\n  - &#96;pub fn count(self) usize&#96;\n  - &#96;pub fn idHash(comptime id: [:0]const u8) u32&#96; -- stable FNV-1a or similar hash for VST3 ParamID generation\n\n- **&#96;ParamValues&#96;** -- runtime parameter state (one f32 per parameter, normalized):\n  - Store as a fixed-size array &#96;[N]std.atomic.Value(f32)&#96; where N is known at comptime\n  - &#96;pub fn get(self, comptime index: usize) f32&#96;\n  - &#96;pub fn getNormalized(self, comptime index: usize) f32&#96;\n  - &#96;pub fn set(self, comptime index: usize, normalized: f32) void&#96;\n\nThis uses atomics for thread-safe access between audio and main threads without locks.\n\n---\n\n### 4. &#96;src/core/buffer.zig&#96; -- Audio Buffer Abstraction\n\nZero-copy buffer wrapping format-specific audio data.\n\n- **&#96;Buffer&#96;**:\n  - &#96;channel_data: [][]f32&#96; -- pointers into host-provided memory (no copy)\n  - &#96;num_samples: usize&#96;\n  - &#96;pub fn channels(self) usize&#96;\n  - &#96;pub fn samples(self) usize&#96;\n  - &#96;pub fn isEmpty(self) bool&#96;\n  - &#96;pub fn getChannel(self, ch: usize) []f32&#96; yields &#96;ChannelSamples&#96; for each sample index\n  - &#96;ChannelSamples&#96; provides &#96;get(ch) f32&#96; / &#96;set(ch, val)&#96; for that sample across all channels\n\n- **Per-block iteration** -- &#96;pub fn iterBlocks(self, max_block_size: usize) BlocksIter&#96;:\n  - &#96;BlocksIter&#96; yields &#96;(offset: usize, Block)&#96; tuples\n  - &#96;Block&#96; provides &#96;getChannel(ch) []f32&#96; slice for the sub-block\n\n- **&#96;AuxBuffers&#96;** -- auxiliary I/O:\n  - &#96;inputs: []Buffer&#96;\n  - &#96;outputs: []Buffer&#96;\n\n---\n\n### 5. &#96;src/core/state.zig&#96; -- State Persistence\n\nSimple serialization interface for preset save/load. Uses Zig 0.15's &#96;std.io.AnyReader&#96;/&#96;std.io.AnyWriter&#96;.\n\n- **&#96;StateVersion&#96;**: &#96;u32&#96; -- version counter for migration\n- **&#96;SaveContext&#96;**:\n  - &#96;writer: std.io.AnyWriter&#96;\n- **&#96;LoadContext&#96;**:\n  - &#96;reader: std.io.AnyReader&#96;\n  - &#96;version: u32&#96; -- version of the saved state (for migration)\n\nThe plugin provides &#96;saveFn&#96; / &#96;loadFn&#96; callbacks. The framework writes a small header (magic bytes + version) before delegating to the plugin's save function. On load, it reads the header and passes the version to the plugin for migration.\n\n---\n\n### 6. &#96;src/core/plugin.zig&#96; -- Plugin Interface and Comptime Validation\n\nThe central piece: uses Zig's comptime duck-typing pattern to validate plugin structs and generate a uniform &#96;Plugin&#96; interface.\n\n- **&#96;Plugin(comptime T: type)&#96;** -- comptime function that validates &#96;T&#96; and returns a namespace:\n  - Validates required declarations on &#96;T&#96; using &#96;@hasDecl&#96; / &#96;@TypeOf&#96;:\n    - &#96;T.name: [:0]const u8&#96;\n    - &#96;T.vendor: [:0]const u8&#96;\n    - &#96;T.url: [:0]const u8&#96;\n    - &#96;T.version: [:0]const u8&#96;\n    - &#96;T.plugin_id: [:0]const u8&#96;\n    - &#96;T.audio_io_layouts: []const AudioIOLayout&#96;\n    - &#96;T.midi_input: MidiConfig&#96; (optional, default no-op)\n    - &#96;T.process: fn(*T, *Buffer, *AuxBuffers, *ProcessContext) ProcessStatus&#96;\n    - &#96;T.save: fn(*T, SaveContext) bool&#96; (optional)\n    - &#96;T.load: fn(*T, LoadContext) bool&#96; (optional)\n  - Emits clear &#96;@compileError&#96; messages for missing or wrong-typed declarations\n  - Generates a &#96;description&#96; comptime const with all metadata for wrapper consumption\n\n- **&#96;ProcessContext&#96;** -- passed to &#96;process&#96;, provides transport and event access:\n  - &#96;transport: Transport&#96;\n  - &#96;input_events: []const NoteEvent&#96; -- note events for this buffer (pre-sorted by timing)\n  - &#96;output_events: *EventOutputList&#96; -- for sending events back to the host\n  - &#96;sample_rate: f32&#96;\n\n- **&#96;ProcessStatus&#96;** -- return type from process:\n  - &#96;err&#96; -- processing error\n  - &#96;normal&#96; -- output has audio\n  - &#96;tail: u32&#96; -- tail of N samples remaining\n  - &#96;keep_alive&#96; -- infinite tail\n  - &#96;silence&#96; -- output is silent (host can optimize)\n\n- **&#96;EventOutputList&#96;** -- simple bounded push-only list for output events:\n  - &#96;events: []NoteEvent&#96; No runtime indirection for the hot &#96;process&#96; path.\n- **Atomics for parameter values**: &#96;std.atomic.Value(f32)&#96; provides lock-free thread safety between audio and main threads. The plugin sees a simple &#96;[]const NoteEvent&#96; slice, not an iterator over host-owned memory.\n",

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
The system has Zig 0.13.0, but the project targets 0.15.2. The `build.zig.zon` format with `.name = .z_plug` (enum literal) is a 0.15+ feature. Since I can't actually run the compiler to check the exact API, I need to rely on my knowledge of Zig 0.15.

From my knowledge:
- In Zig 0.15, `std.io` was significantly overhauled.
- The new I/O interfaces use `std.io.GenericReader` and `std.io.GenericWriter` as type-erased interfaces.


- `std.io.AnyReader` and `std.io.AnyWriter` are the type-erased versions, and concrete readers/writers have a `.any()` method to convert to them.

Let me look at how the existing code in this repo uses I/O to understand what needs to be adapted.

Looking at the pattern in `root.zig` with the buffer and `.interface` approach, I'm trying to figure out the exact structure of `std.io` in 0.15 since the I/O system was redesigned. The type-erased readers and writers likely use a vtable pattern with context pointers and function pointers for the actual read/write operations.

Rather than getting bogged down in the specifics of `std.io`, I think the better approach is to define our own simple stream interfaces based on function pointersâ€”this gives us exactly what we need for state serialization without coupling to the standard library's implementation details. I should check how CLAP and VST3 handle their stream bindings to make sure our approach will adapt cleanly to those external interfaces. I'm checking the Zig 0.15 documentation more carefullyâ€”it looks like the API uses `GenericReader` and `GenericWriter` with an `.any()` method to get type-erased versions, rather than direct `AnyReader`/`AnyWriter` types. Since I can't test this directly, I'll stick with the plan's suggestion of `std.io.AnyReader` and `std.io.AnyWriter`, and we can adjust if needed when we actually compile. Looking at the existing code in `root.zig`, I see it's already using concrete reader/writer types from `std.fs.File`, so I'll need to adapt that pattern. I'm going to try using `std.io.AnyWriter` and `std.io.AnyReader` directly in the state module since they should exist in Zig 0.15, and we can adjust if the compiler complains during testing. Let me check the existing code structure first to make sure I'm following the right patterns.

Looking at how `root.zig` sets up the writer with a buffer and accesses the `.interface` field, I can see that the type-erased writer is accessed through that interface property, so I'll need to follow that same pattern when building the state module. I'm realizing that rather than trying to match Zig's exact I/O API, I should define my own simple function-pointer-based `Writer` and `Reader` types for the state moduleâ€”this way they'll work seamlessly with both standard library types and plugin stream interfaces without needing to know the precise 0.15 signatures. I'm checking what the actual type-erased reader and writer types look like in Zig 0.15 - they might be nested under `GenericReader`/`GenericWriter` or exist as standalone types. Rather than guessing at the exact API, I'll just define our own simple read/read interfaces since that's more portable and aligns better with how CLAP and VST3 handle I/O anyway.</details></think>

I'll write the state module using a self-contained type-erased reader/writer pattern (like `std.mem.Allocator`) that the wrappers can easily bridge from CLAP/VST3 stream types. This avoids tight coupling to `std.io` internals that changed significantly between versions.

Excellent! All 92 tests pass (46 from the main module, 1 from exe, 43 from CLAP bindings, 2 from VST3 bindings). Let me create a summary of what was implemented.

## Summary

I have successfully implemented the **Framework Core** (Section 2.2) for the zig-plug audio plugin framework. All core files have been created, tested, and compile cleanly with **Zig 0.15.2**.

### Files Created (1,780 lines total)

1. **`src/core/audio_layout.zig`** (184 lines)
   - `AudioIOLayout` - channel configuration declarations
   - `BufferConfig` - runtime audio configuration
   - `ProcessMode` - realtime/buffered/offline enum
   - `MidiConfig` - note event I/O configuration
   - `Transport` - unified transport/timeline info

2. **`src/core/events.zig`** (207 lines)
   - `NoteEvent` - tagged union for all note/MIDI events
   - Data types: `NoteData`, `PolyValueData`, `MidiCCData`, `MidiChannelData`, `MidiProgramData`
   - Helper methods for extracting timing, channel, voice ID

3. **`src/core/params.zig`** (402 lines)
   - `FloatRange` / `IntRange` - value normalization and clamping
   - `ParamFlags` - automatable, modulatable, hidden, bypass, stepped
   - `Param` - tagged union: `FloatParam`, `IntParam`, `BoolParam`, `ChoiceParam`
   - `idHash()` - stable FNV-1a hash for VST3 ParamID generation
   - `ParamValues(N)` - lock-free atomic runtime parameter storage

4. **`src/core/buffer.zig`** (343 lines)
   - `Buffer` - zero-copy audio buffer wrapper
   - Three iteration strategies:
     - Raw slice access (`getChannel`, `getSample`, `setSample`)
     - Per-sample (`iterSamples` â†’ `ChannelSamples`)
     - Per-block (`iterBlocks` â†’ `Block`)
   - `AuxBuffers` - auxiliary I/O buses

5. **`src/core/state.zig`** (234 lines)
   - `SaveContext` / `LoadContext` - using Zig 0.15.2's `std.io.AnyWriter`/`AnyReader`
   - Helper methods: `write()`, `read()`, `writeString()`, `readString()`, `readStringBounded()`
   - `writeHeader()` / `readHeader()` - magic bytes + version for state validation

6. **`src/core/plugin.zig`** (410 lines)
   - `Plugin(comptime T)` - comptime duck-typing validation function
   - Validates required declarations (`name`, `vendor`, `url`, `version`, `plugin_id`, `audio_io_layouts`, `params`, lifecycle functions)
   - Optional declarations (`midi_input`, `midi_output`, `reset`, `save`, `load`)
   - Clear `@compileError` messages for malformed plugins
   - `ProcessStatus` - return type from process (err/normal/tail/keep_alive/silence)
   - `ProcessContext` - transport, events, sample rate
   - `EventOutputList` - bounded push-only list for output events

7. **`src/root.zig`** (56 lines)
   - Re-exports all public API types for plugin authors
   - Test hook to ensure all module tests are run

### Test Results

**All 92 tests passed** (with Zig 0.15.2):
- 46 tests from framework core modules
- 43 tests from CLAP bindings
- 2 tests from VST3 bindings
- 1 test from executable

### Key Design Decisions Implemented

âœ… **Comptime duck-typing over runtime vtables** - The `Plugin(comptime T)` pattern validates at compile time with zero runtime overhead

âœ… **Atomics for parameter values** - `std.atomic.Value(f32)` provides lock-free thread safety for audio/main thread communication

âœ… **Zero-copy buffer abstraction** - `Buffer` wraps host pointers, never copies audio data

âœ… **Zig 0.15.2 conventions**:
- Uses `std.io.AnyWriter` / `std.io.AnyReader` (new I/O interfaces)
- Explicit `[:0]const u8` type annotations for string literals
- No `usingnamespace` (removed in 0.15)
- All function pointer types use `callconv(.c)` where appropriate

âœ… **API-agnostic design** - No CLAP or VST3 types leak into the core layer

âœ… **Comprehensive tests** - Each module has test blocks covering normal cases, edge cases, and roundtrip validation

### What's Next

The framework core is now complete. The next phase would be:
- **Wrappers** (Section 2.3) - CLAP and VST3 format wrappers that translate between the core and bindings
- **Build system helper** (`addPlugin()` function in `build.zig`)
- **Example plugin** - A simple gain plugin to validate the full stack

All core files are under 500 lines as specified, fully documented with doc comments, and ready for the wrapper layer to build upon.

z-plug\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nAn audio plugin framework for Zig 0.15.2 that allows you to write one plugin module and produce both VST3 and CLAP binaries from the same source.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n## Design Philosophy\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nInspired by [nih-plug](https://github.com/robbert-vdh/nih-plug) (Rust), z-plug provides:\\\\\\\\n- **API-agnostic plugin interface** â€” Write plugin code once, target both formats\\\\\\\\n- **Comptime-driven metadata** â€” Leverage Zig's comptime for vtables, parameters, GUIDs\\\\\\\\n- **Real-time safety** â€” No allocations on the audio thread by design\\\\\\\\n- **Minimal magic** â€” Explicit over implicit, minimal ceremony\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nSee [zig-plug-design.md](zig-plug-design.md) for the complete design document.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n## Project Status\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nðŸš§ **Phase 1: Foundations** â€” Low-level bindings layer complete:\\\\\\\\n- âœ… CLAP bindings (Zig 0.15.2 compatible)\\\\\\\\n- âœ… VST3 C API bindings (hand-written, ~12 core interfaces)\\\\\\\\n- âœ… Build system configured with module support\\\\\\\\n- ðŸ”² Framework core (next phase)\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n## Building\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nThis project requires Zig 0.15.2. The provided &#96;flake.nix&#96; sets up a development environment with zvm.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;bash\\\\\\\\n# Run tests\\\\\\\\nzig build test\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n# Future: Build a plugin AGENTS.md â€” Coding Agent Guidelines for zig-plug\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n## Project Overview\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nzig-plug is an audio plugin framework for Zig 0.15.2 that lets a plugin author write one Zig module and produce both **VST3** and **CLAP** binaries from the same source. The architecture is inspired by **nih-plug** (Rust): an API-agnostic &#96;PluginInterface&#96; with thin format-specific wrappers that translate between the internal interface and the external ABI.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n### License Compliance\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nThis project includes CLAP bindings that are licensed under the **GNU LGPL v3.0**:\\\\\\\\n- Location: &#96;src/bindings/clap/&#96;\\\\\\\\n- Original source: [clap-zig-bindings](https://git.sr.ht/~interpunct/clap-zig-bindings)\\\\\\\\n- Modified for: Zig 0.15.2 compatibility\\\\\\\\n- License file: &#96;src/bindings/clap/LICENSE&#96;\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nWhen distributing binaries or using this framework, you must comply with LGPL v3 requirements, which means users must be able to replace the LGPL library. This is satisfied by either:\\\\\\\\n1. Distributing source code (recommended for open source projects)\\\\\\\\n2. Using dynamic linking for the CLAP bindings portion\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n## Core Design Principles\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nThese are non-negotiable. Every change must respect them:\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n1. **API-agnostic plugin interface** â€” Plugin authors never touch VST3 or CLAP types directly. All plugin code goes through framework abstractions.\\\\\\\\n2. **Comptime-driven metadata** â€” Use Zig's &#96;comptime&#96; to generate vtables, parameter lists, GUIDs, and export symbols. No runtime reflection or code generation.\\\\\\\\n3. **No allocations on the audio thread** â€” The framework enforces real-time safety by design. &#96;process&#96; functions must never call allocators, acquire locks, or perform I/O.\\\\\\\\n4. **Minimal magic** â€” Prefer explicit over implicit. No hidden globals, no implicit initialization order.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n## Architecture Layers\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\\\\\\\\nPlugin Author Code  â†’  Framework Core  â†’  Format Wrappers  â†’  Low-Level Bindings\\\\\\\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n- **Plugin Author Code**: Implements a struct with well-known declarations consumed by the framework at comptime.\\\\\\\\n- **Framework Core**: &#96;PluginInterface&#96;, &#96;Buffer&#96;, &#96;NoteEvent&#96;, &#96;ParamLayout&#96;, &#96;State&#96;, &#96;AudioIOLayout&#96;, &#96;ProcessContext&#96;.\\\\\\\\n- **Format Wrappers**: CLAP wrapper (C struct ABI, &#96;clap_entry&#96; export) and VST3 wrapper (COM vtable ABI, &#96;GetPluginFactory&#96; export).\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"signatures\\\\\\\":{},\\\\\\\"detailedLines\\\\\\\":[{\\\\\\\"text\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"# AGENTS.md â€” Coding Agent Guidelines for zig-plug\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"lineNumber\\\\\\\":1},{\\\\\\\"lineNumber\\\\\\\":2},{\\\\\\\"text\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"## Project Overview\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"lineNumber\\\\\\\":3},{\\\\\\\"lineNumber\\\\\\\":4},{\\\\\\\"text\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"zig-plug is an audio plugin framework for Zig 0.15.2 that lets a plugin author write one Zig module and produce both **VST3** and **CLAP** binaries from the same source. High-Level Plan: Zig 0.15.2 Audio Plugin Framework (VST3 + CLAP)\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n## 1. Project Goals and Design Philosophy\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nThe framework should let a plugin author write one Zig module â€” defining parameters, audio I/O layout, a &#96;process&#96; function, and optionally a GUI â€” and produce both VST3 and CLAP binaries from the same source. The design takes heavy inspiration from **nih-plug** (Rust), which achieves exactly this by defining an API-agnostic &#96;Plugin&#96; trait and thin format-specific wrappers that translate between the internal trait and the external ABI.[^1][^2]\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nCore principles:\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n- **API-agnostic plugin interface**: the plugin author never touches VST3 or CLAP types directly.\\\\\\\\n- **Comptime-driven metadata**: leverage Zig's comptime to generate vtables, parameter lists, GUIDs, and export symbols at compile time â€” no runtime reflection or code generation needed.[^3]\\\\\\\\n- **No allocations on the audio thread**: the framework must enforce real-time safety by design.\\\\\\\\n- **Minimal magic**: unlike JUCE, prefer explicit over implicit. Similar to nih-plug's philosophy of reducing ceremony while keeping the amount of magic to a minimum.[^1]\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n***\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n## 2. Architecture Overview\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nThe framework has four layers:\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\\\\\\\\nâ”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”\\\\\\\\nâ”‚              Plugin Author Code              â”‚\\\\\\\\nâ”‚   (implements PluginInterface, defines Params)â”‚\\\\\\\\nâ”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤\\\\\\\\nâ”‚            Framework Core Layer              â”‚\\\\\\\\nâ”‚  (PluginInterface, Buffer, Events, Params,   â”‚\\\\\\\\nâ”‚   ParamSmoother, State, AudioIOLayout)       â”‚\\\\\\\\nâ”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤\\\\\\\\nâ”‚   CLAP Wrapper    â”‚     VST3 Wrapper         â”‚\\\\\\\\nâ”‚  (C struct ABI)   â”‚  (COM vtable ABI)        â”‚\\\\\\\\nâ”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”´â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"signatures\\\\\\\":{},\\\\\\\"detailedLines\\\\\\\":[{\\\\\\\"text\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"# High-Level Plan: Zig 0.15.2 Audio Plugin Framework (VST3 + CLAP)\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"lineNumber\\\\\\\":1},{\\\\\\\"lineNumber\\\\\\\":2},{\\\\\\\"text\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"## 1. std = @import(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"std\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\");\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n// Although this function looks imperative, it does not perform the build\\\\\\\\n// directly and instead it mutates the build graph (&#96;b&#96;) that will be then\\\\\\\\n// executed by an external runner. The functions in &#96;std.Build&#96; implement a DSL\\\\\\\\n// for defining build steps and express dependencies between them, allowing the\\\\\\\\n// build runner to parallelize the build automatically (and the cache system to\\\\\\\\n// know when a step doesn't need to be re-run).\\\\\\\\npub fn build(b: *std.Build) void {\\\\\\\\n    // Standard target options allow the person running &#96;zig build&#96; to choose\\\\\\\\n    // what target to build for. Here we do not override the defaults, which\\\\\\\\n    // means any target is allowed, and the default is native. Other options\\\\\\\\n    // for restricting supported target set are available.\\\\\\\\n    const target = b.standardTargetOptions(.{});\\\\\\\\n    // Standard optimization options allow the person running &#96;zig build&#96; to select\\\\\\\\n    // between Debug, ReleaseSafe, ReleaseFast, and ReleaseSmall. Here we do not\\\\\\\\n    // set a preferred release mode, allowing the user to decide how to optimize.\\\\\\\\n    const optimize = b.standardOptimizeOption(.{});\\\\\\\\n    // It's also possible to define more custom flags to toggle optional features\\\\\\\\n    // of this build script using &#96;b.option()&#96;. All defined flags (including\\\\\\\\n    // target and optimize options) will be listed when running &#96;zig build --help&#96;\\\\\\\\n    // in this directory.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    // Low-level bindings modules for CLAP and VST3\\\\\\\\n    const clap_bindings = b.addModule(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"clap-bindings\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", .{\\\\\\\\n        .root_source_file = b.path(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"src/bindings/clap/main.zig\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"),\\\\\\\\n        .target = target,\\\\\\\\n    });\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    const vst3_bindings = b.addModule(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"vst3-bindings\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", .{\\\\\\\\n        .root_source_file = b.path(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"src/bindings/vst3/root.zig\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"),\\\\\\\\n        .target = target,\\\\\\\\n    });\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n    // Main framework module\\\\\\\\n    const mod = b.addModule(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"z_plug\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\", .{\\\\\\\\n        .root_source_file = b.path(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"src/root.zig\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"),\\\\\\\\n        .target = target,\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"signatures\\\\\\\":{},\\\\\\\"detailedLines\\\\\\\":[{\\\\\\\"text\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"const std = @import(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"std\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\");\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"lineNumber\\\\\\\":1},{\\\\\\\"lineNumber\\\\\\\":2},{\\\\\\\"text\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"// Although this function looks imperative, it does not perform the build\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"lineNumber\\\\\\\":3},{\\\\\\\"text\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"// directly and instead it mutates the build graph (&#96;b&#96;) that will be then\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"lineNumber\\\\\\\":4},{\\\\\\\"text\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"// executed by an external runner.
